summary: Good on resume for next opportunity
pros:
Bold people
Willing to take risk
A lot to do
cons:
No life, just work
Too much doc writing 
Too many things at same time

summary: A place to learn and grow if you want to build your own path
pros: Great opportunity to learn. Often not micromanaged. Lots of horizontal opportunities and projects available for those interested.
cons: RTO. Mediocre benefits. Culture has taken a noticeable decline over the years.

summary: Don’t join
pros: Used to be a good name in your resume. Not anymore.
cons:
TC keeps decreasing year by year.
Rto5. Very political work environment.

summary: Good training, decent pay, horrible culture
pros: Pays decently especially with RSUs. Fast-paced and you learn a lot. Good resume material.
cons: Cut-throat culture that's more competitive than collaborative. Very beaurocracy heavy

summary: Great for learning but mediocre managers and career growth
pros: Lot of opportunities to learn and move around internally to explore various domains
cons: Mediocre management, lot of top-down culture and career growth is slow and often dependent on too many variables

summary: Good pay terrible wlb
pros: Pay is good and leadership principles help you learn and acquire new soft skills.
cons: There are toxic people almost in every team. No appealing benefit

summary: WLB sucks, but a great 1st FAANG company to start off with
pros: Impactful work, smart colleagues, decent career growth. Comparatively easy FAANG to get into.
cons: WLB sucks, compensation isn’t great at all, too much red tape and bureaucracy.

summary: Not a place for everyone, buy was for me ay least
pros:
Lots of learning and growth opportunities.
Really smart and hard-working people.
Work on products that impact many people's lives.
cons:
Company is frugal, nothing I can say as perk.
24 hours oncall.
Changing priorities.
Managers can affect many aspects of your life and work.

summary: Toxic company
pros: Probably larger scope if this is your thing and you can get promoted fast if you are tt
cons: Toxic culture. Mindless management. Peanut compensations. Hire high bar for low levels.

summary: Honestly its good for getting a brand name on your resume and thats it
pros: After working at Amazon, my "prestige" in the job market went up significantly (easier to land interviews etc). BUT this is a benefit of any FAANG level company. Other than than, if you can land the right team its not so bad work-wise either.
cons: PIP-culture, heavy on-call, some teams are incredibly toxic and cut-throat. Again Amazon is usually very team dependant.

summary: No wlb
pros: Good pay, bad leadership, low impact, too slow org, okay okay
cons: Bad culture, Good pay, bad leadership, low impact, too slow org

summary: Great for career growth
pros: A lot of talent and opportunity to learn, very high standards
cons: VERY different experience based on what team/manager you are on. Compensation outside the US drops significantly.

summary: 4 Years. Is it a good time to end?
pros:
Get promotions to L5 in Q1 2023 so TC these 2 years are great(ignore the stock diving recently).

Stay in a retail org so not much work to do.
cons: Toxic management and L6 SDEs joined the team last year. Unfair management.

summary: Chaotic culture
pros: Fair compensation, opportunity to work with some good people with great technical skills.
cons: Return to hub mandate. Oncall load can be heavy. Reorg happens very often, which impact career growth opportunities

summary: Some teams there is tremendous growth
pros: Steep learning by curve and lots of growth in the right team.
cons: Bureaucracy has increased a lot affecting productivity and innovation. Managers need to go and lean team will make an effective team.

summary: Good place for new grad to learn things
pros: A lot of things can be learned here. A lot of large scale systems.
cons: Bad management leading to bad work life balance and bad support on career support. Time is wasted on beaureaucracy.

summary: Good place for career growth
pros: Amazon is a good spot to grow your career (assuming you land on a good team). The work-life balance can be surprisingly good, and the doc-heavy culture is something I wish other companies would adopt.
cons: Culture can be hit or miss depending on your team. The compensation is okay, although their vesting schedule (backloaded) is particularly bad. That combined with assumed stock growth often reduces compensation.

summary: Bad career growth, bad comp, bad benefits, bad management
pros: * You can switch teams internally. Some require simple discussions while others require full-fledged interviews.
cons:
* Managers can be friends, but do something really bad for your careers
* PIP / Focus is unfair.
* High gap in compensation between internally promoted vs external hires.
* Benefits are not all useful. You get 1-2% discount on random stuff that noone buys. Cult membership discount is the only good benefit.
* Cafetarias are lacking in comparison to other big 4 companies.

summary: Team dependent
pros: Strong ownership if you are willing to take it and act upon it
cons: Too many variables outside of control , can feel too ambiguous.

summary: Good internal mobility
pros: Opportunities for internal mobility between teams and orgs. Lots of exposure to different industries and businesses
cons: Culture varies by team and lots of new external hires means inconsistent org mechanisms, expectations, and values

summary: Great place to grow
pros: Amazon is huge that gives everyone an opportunity to learn and grow along with good compensation.
cons: No work life balance in most departments and Toxic culture by managers

summary: If you want to hustle unreasonably
pros: Impactful Work and fast paced . . . . .
cons: Not so good WLB/Benefits. . . . . . .

summary: Mehr
pros:
High impact work
Not bad pay
Good recognition on your resume and among friends
cons:
Tiny increase on TC
Toxic pip culture
Hard to get promoted
In

summary: Surprisingly decent WLB
pros: Very nice team, although this is hugely random and not something to bet on
cons: Not much career progression, getting senior is very difficult - also lots of changing priorities in projects

summary: Promising growth for junior level employees
pros: Rotation opportunities for career pivot, promotion fast track for junior employees at L4 and L5 levels.
cons: Work life balance is bad. Frequent reorg and change of leadership direction

summary: Eh ok but not great long term
pros: I had ok managers but communication was sparse and timelines were shaky
cons: There was no room for career growth and it got depressing by the end
reasonResign: I did not fee confident in my role there and in my ability to level up my career

summary: Lot to learn
pros: Data oriented, lot to learn and new cloud tech and ML can be learned for free
cons:
5 days 
Return to office , no free food or snack

summary: Horrible WLB
pros: Learn a lot of stuff in much shorter time, great if you're new grad and jump after 2 years
cons: Everything else, wlb, pay, politics, people. Amazon is a data company when it comes to promotions but apparently you need to be lucky to get compensated well (a bottom SDE2 can make less salary than a SDE1 because the stock might not be doing good this year)

summary: A great experience(not AWS)
pros: I left Amazon about two years ago(2022) after working there for one year(2021-2022) as an L4 Software Engineer in the consumer organization. The managers were good and planned some career growth for me. They were also kind and allowed me to choose between frontend, backend, or mobile projects.
cons: However, the salary wasn't competitive compared to other "Big N" companies, and the refreshers were minimal, only a few thousand.

summary: Way behind the curve on analytics
pros: Office is close to home, good colleagues , some learning in terms of writing culture
cons: No growth, just reporting and back end work, horrible office politics
